This is a 1 part clip on guard to protect the props on your Hubsan X4 Mini Quad Copter.

I used 0.2 mm layer height and 0.1 infill although the layer height shouldn't mater to much.
I printed in black abs to match my quad but any colour will do. 
The part weighs in at around 4 grams when printed in ABS. I don't know how much this would change with PLA. 
I have found the battery life to be slightly shorter (as expected) but its worth it for the added protection from flying into things whilst learning.
This part could be made thinner to decrease weight but this will also make it weaker, I have not had time to experiment yet.
FITTING: this part can be put on and taken off without removing the blades. first hook around all motors (turn the props so that they fit through if needed) then push the centre clips so that they press against the bottom of the body.

comments.text: Just printed one for my x4. The I couldn't really tell a difference in the batter life from the added weight form the original prop guard. Need to weigh them though. Fun print. Thanks for the file

description.text:
This is a model of Nikola Tesla's Wardenclyffe World Wireless Tower.
This model was originally crafted by Verislav Mudrak. I've only sliced it in half and added a smooth cupola to go with it. Please read the instructions before printing!

Rescaled and printed at 30% size on the MakerBot 5th Gen (TeslaTowerOnly, z = 122.29mm). I printed with rafts. Try not to scale this model too small because it has many small structures. UPDATE 12/27/14 -
The wireframe model of the cupola is nearly impossible to print at a small scale. If you are successful please upload your pictures! In its place I have provided a smooth surface cupola designed to fit the z = 122.29mm TeslaTowerOnly model (TeslaTowerCupolaPrintable file). It serves the purpose however is not true to the original design. My apologies. Print the tower separate from the cupola and C/A glue them together. I've also included split cupola files for those of you who are feeling lucky!

description.text:
This is a high resolution .stl for a 40mm radial fan.  When printed the fan has a diameter of 40mm with a height of 13mm.  I attached mine to a motor with a 2mm shaft to test it out.
If you would like to see some alterations made, feel free to post your request under comments.

There are 2 versions of this fan.
Fan.stl is designed to be printed out with "exterior only" support.  By doing so it creates support structure underneath the fan blades.  The upper ring should come out fine if you have your settings tuned right.
FAN Solid Bottom.stl has a solid bottom plate so that it can be printed without any support.

Wooden railways are great fun but they shouldn't be seen as simply a younger child's version of an electric train set (nor as a boy's toy rather than a girl's toy). Electric trains are operated remotely, but wooden trains are very much hands on - the youngster has to make the decision as to which direction the train will take at a junction, for example, and physically push the train in that direction.  
I've collected my information from a number of sources and from the Little Shop of Knowledge.   
I have test fitted the parts to Imaginarium train set, Melissa & Doug train set and to Disney's Cars wooden roads, and the fit perfectly.  
In the download section, you can find the original SketchUp drawing file, and you can play with it, assemble sets and what not before you go ahead and print parts.  
I have not made the parts "reversible", so, you have to print "left" and "right" parts. In all my attempts, the track when printed "reversible" was not smooth, which made me opt for single side tracks.  
There are 28 parts total. Tracks, pillars, ramps, bridges, etc.  
Enjoy.

author: Stargate

description.text:
Spool holder designed for the MTU MOST Delta printer, but adjustable for probably many other printers. Feel free to extend it for yours! Search for B4PRINT in source to see what to change, but in a nutshell:
  • ensure spool dimensions are correct
  • ensure the hook will hang as you'd like
    • The code is set up with a "simple" hanging scheme, but I have ideas for others. If you have a specific design you want for your printer (to place the spool somewhere convenient or have multiple spools on one hanger) extend the code and drop me a note! I have included a quick spool model with this code and the "%" modifier is used to show the spool and the crossmember for debugging/design. It does not get included with the final .STL. (See screenshot.) v2 includes more code comments, the .STL output does not change between versions.

title: Arduino 4 Relay Module Bottom Cover Plate with Wall Mount

description.text:
This design covers the entire bottom of the arduino 4 channel relay board so if you running 120v you won't shock yourself and it gives you 2 screw holes to mount this module.  
The design takes 10-15m to print and uses 2000mm of plastic. The part is a snug fit so check your printers calibration is within around 1mm. Be careful removing the part from the build platform, the base is 2 layers thick but it has lots of surface area to stick.   
Be careful with the 4 posts, they are thin and will snap off if you are applying too much pressure to get the board into the cover.

comments.text: I find I had to scale this in repetier-host to make it fit properly.
comments.author: drbogger

author: sztech

description.text:
This is a PCB Heatbed for the eMAKER Huxley, but should work on any 3D printer which has a 140x140mm print area.
Thanks to prusajr for the information provided in his PCB heatbed, thing:2172, from which this thing is derived.
Track widths are set to give 4.5Ohms at 25C, rising to 6.6Ohms at 150C (for standard 35um copper cladding). For a 19v power supply, this gives a power output of between 80W and 54W.

I printed this on press'n'peel which irons on to a bare PCB, then etched it.
The thermistor solders onto the centre of the board. I then painted the track with black stove paint.

description.text: Zeepro Zim uses a proprietary cartridge system. In my experience, this cartridge design is prone to jamming, and is not easily refillable. This is the first attempt to address these issues by creating an accessory that allows bypassing the stock cartridge but still use the spool and base plate with the RFID tag. These two parts are designed to allow using the RFID plate without the cartridge top. This makes removing and replacing the spools easier, at the expense of having to reset the cartridge information each time a spool is replaced. It also allows the filament to unspool with less interference.

Using this accessory requires disassembling the Zim cartridge. I recommend creating a new preset based on "Fast" with supportes disabled and "autofan" enabled. The supports are not needed for the small bridges involved with this design.   
Only the bottom RFID plate and the spool (minus the spool cover) will be used with these parts. The black o-ring around the filament can also be removed and set aside.   
The filament guide should site over the slot in the neck of the RFID plate, towards the bottom feed stepper. It is to ensure filament is guided into the stepper correctly. I have found that this piece is not really necessary, but can't hurt to ensure the feed is working smoothly. There is a slot in the top that is designed to accept a zip tie to hold this piece in place. A friction fit also works. Finally, there is a screw hole underneath for a 4-40 sized screw, if you want to hold this piece permanently to the base and provide more stiffness to the neck piece of the bottom plate.  
The larger back piece snaps on to the RFID plate and serves two purposes. First, there is a bit of a lip that holds the spool in place should it tangle and start to lift off the center pin. Second, it is designed to fit the clips in the back of the cartridge holder to provide tension holding down the bottom RFID plate, and spring tension on the neck against the bottom stepper pinion.

title: Prusa i3 Rework capazitive/inductive Z-Probe Holder

description.text:
This is my Z-Probe Holder for my Prusa i3 Rework with the standart emotionTec extruder. It uses a inductive/capazitive Sensor with 17-18mm outer diameter. I would recommend printing this with 100% infill, because you want it to be very robust.
I also included the Solid Works file, in case anybody wants to edit it. I hope you enjoy the conveniance of auto bed leveling or tramming or whatever you wanna call it! :-)

You need a well adjusted Prusa i3. Make sure, that it can print without the auto bed leveling and tune it, until you are satisfied with the results. Then print out the Probe Holder. Install the Probe and connect it to the Electronics. (I won't cover the installation of the electronics, because there are many different probe types... (NPN, PNP; NO, NC)) Make sure that the probe is working by typing M119 in the machine control panel. If the probe is triggered you should get a reading like: Zmin = TRIGGERED. Under files you also find the full firmware folder. My endstops for x is right and for y it is in the front. Don't simply use my configuration, you need to edit some settings, for example for your hotend. Then you need to adjust the auto bed leveling settings. The offsets are: "#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 38"
"#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -25" Note that the algebraic sign of the offsets can vary depending on your endstop configuration. The Z offset you will need to find out yourself, I found mine by Trial and Error... :-) I won't cover the other auto level settings, because there are many videos on youtube. If you have questions simply contact me.

description.text: This is my version of the mantis router, http://makeyourbot.org/mantis9-1 as designed originally by David Carr. This design is adapted to metric sizes (do away with Henry IV's thumb!)and enlarged to a groundplate of 30x30 cm. The working volume is slightly more than 190 x 130 x 40 mm, depending on how precise you work.

I used a larger CNC router to cut out the wood pieces, I suggest you do the same. The material used is 12mm birch ply (that's ~1/2"), but any reasonably straight plywood should do.

I designed in Rhino3d (for want of something equal but open source on linux...)so the rhino file should be read as authorative, the dxf file is there for your convenience. There are several layers in there prefixed with a number, Follow the instructive layer names in that order. An offset for 3mm drill and 5mm router bits is supplied, but you can of course generate your own... further (probably incomplete or outdated) instructions here: http://wiki.protospace.nl/index.php/MantisRouter. [EDIT]: I updated the plans to use a more common 'fake dremel' and added lots of extra tweaks. The nesting as it is now is tailored to a 5mm flat tip bit, with unneeded (double) cutting paths deleted. Those of you in the US might have to generate a new cutting path to accommodate an imperial size bit. [/EDIT]

remixed_from.title: Bottle cap mount for Go Pro

description.text: I was impressed by Marcella's idea of a bottle mount for a go pro (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:503338), and equally impressed by UltiArjan's idea of a magnetic mount (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:291363), so decided to get the best of both worlds! I ended up adapting this really nice and clean bottle cap by ahoeben (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:148310) to add the magnetic tripod since Marcella's is a bit too elaborate to modify. Oh it also works as a simple tripod stand in its own right as well.

I found that three 6mm x 3mm neo magnets do the trick nicely - but they would slide down my fridge in earlier versions, and in some positions they would detach.  I added extra stabilising legs so it doesn't matter how the camera is oriented, and I added notches on the stabilisers so I could add some small rubber bands to add enough friction to stop any slippage.  
I printed at 0.2mm layer height and single shell with 33% fill which seems pretty robust so far.  I then super glued the magnets in place - the notch in the magnet holders gives a bit of flexibility and makes it easier to fit them.  
The photos are from v.2, I have uploaded v.3 which has slightly modified stabiliser legs - cleaner notches for the rubber bands and rounded ends to stop it being so stabby.

comments.text: Great design!  I'm very excited to try this but I am having trouble printing this.  Everything comes out perfect but I can not clear the supports inside the "bottle cap".  It is not as thick as the body, but much thicker than the normal supports that can be easily flicked away.  Can anyone give some adivce?
comments.author: mathrockstar

comments.text:
Hi,
I didn't use any support when I printed it, and it works fine - so that would be my advice :-) As I recall I made the interior 'ceiling' slightly domed to avoid any bridging problems.
Cheers,
Blippy

description.text: a component that is repeated over and over to create a space frame roof support system for a long span structure. This object was created as part of an architecture project at the University of Illinois by Peter Eichberger

Busted a Christmas tree when it was blown over this year.
I discovered it was simply a small plastic "joiner" between the metal sections, so I set about designing a new one - 20 min later here we are! You may like to scale this to suit your needs. The base is 17mm, the square hole is 11mm, and the inner round hole is 8mm. The upper section is 8mm Hole, 10.75mm on the square, and should fit right into the lower section. Inventor and autocad source available on request.
This thing was made with Tinkercad by my son Gavin. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/cCoMW6GVxuz

title: Synchromesh Cable drive pulley, forced motor shaft fit

description.text:
Drive pulley for 3.81mm pitch synchromesh cable found at SPD.   
12T synchromesh Pulley is the updated version. Please try this one first.   
Print with NO support, 0.1mm stepping and slighly overextrude for better fusing :)

Here is a printable Synchromesh drive pulley for 3.81mm pitch cable with a simple interference fit
May take some iterations to get the absolutely correct size. You know you're there when the pulley can only just be pushed on to the shaft with some force. Printed perfect with 0.15mm steppings on z, PLA, and slow print speed. This is work in progress!

Redid it, more printer friendly !   
Pring with 0.1 or 0.15 stepping, works best with 0.3 mm extruding hole, over extrude a little and you will have yourself a perfect synchromesh pulley !

title: 80/20 mount for Sharp IR distance sensor

description.text: This is a set of mounts that attach one of the common IR distance sensors by Sharp (datasheet here: http://sharp-world.com/products/device/lineup/data/pdf/datasheet/gp2y0a02_e.pdf ) to a section of 80/20 profile (more about 80/20 here: http://8020inc.net/ ).

I've included the Sketchup files so you can riff on the design. You should be able to print the STLs without modification, though. (Actually! You may need to convert the STL units from inches->mm to get this the right scale, sorry!) Please note, the parts are "handed" - you'll need one of each handedness to attach a sensor. You may also need to modify/remove the female JST housing on the sensor, which can be accomplished with some flush cutters.
Additionally, as much as it pains me to use imperial units, this piece is for fractional, NOT metric, 80/20 profiles form the "10" series.

A remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11978 to remove the top bar in the links and instead provide springy clips which can be easily removed and replaced to keep the cables in the chain, while still allowing them to be replaced without having to thread everything through from the end. The files named CableChain*.stl are included here, but came from thing 11978 (though the fixed version here had to be run through the netfabb repair service). See a dry run of a chain attached to my solidoodle at http://youtu.be/j9XkiM4_Mn4 I've also included a couple of Solidoodle specific parts for mounting the cable chain ends on the extruder and the back of the case and included a part extracted from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:111213 The original version of this thing used bits of 1.75mm filament instead of springy clips, but it was too easy to break the filament. The springs work much better. The long drawn out description and history of this thing can be found at http://tomhorsley.com/hardware/solidoodle/solidoodle-chain.html

The files included with this thing fall into a few different categories.

  • new-chain.scad

    The main openscad source file with all the module definitions.

    • The parts for the cable chain itself:

  • nobar_sixteen.stl, nobar_sixteen.scad

    An array of 16 cable chain links (will fit on a 6 inch bed).

  • spring_sixteen.stl, spring_sixteen.scad

    An array of 16 spring clips used to close the links.

  • end_two.stl, end_two.scad

    The two cable chain end pieces.

    • Solidoodle specific parts I used for mounting the cable chain:

  • barclip.stl, barclip.scad

    Special clip to hold a 8mm bar just above the top of the Solidoodle for the chain slide on. I needed to print this with the detect thin walls option in slic3r or the support in the front didn't print.

  • extruder-chain-mount.stl, extruder-chain-mount.scad

    Complicated infrastructure built on top of the mk5 extruder filament clip. Definitely needs to print with supports.

  • filament-cap.stl, filament-cap.scad

    Cap to go over the top filament guide on the extruder-chain-mount to keep the filament from snaeking out of the guide.

  • top-chain-mount.stl, top-chain-mount.scad

    Special clip to go in the back corner of the Solidoodle to mount the cable chain and allow the cables to drop through a hole to the motherboard on the back of the printer.

    • Files extracted from thing 11978:
  • CableChain.stl
  • CableChainEnds_fixed.stl
  • end1_fixed.stl
  • end2_fixed.stl
    • File extracted from thing 111213:
  • mk5_extruder_filament_guide_fixed.stl
    • Obsolete old version of new-chain.scad included in case anyone actually wants the version that used bits of filament in place of the spring clips (but I don't recommend this version):
  • bad-chain.scad
    • To print just the cable chain, print one copy of end_two.stl and as many copies of nobar_sixteen.stl and spring_sixteen.stl as you need to make the chain as long as desired. The pieces simply clip together, and the ends have bolt holes for mounting. For my Solidoodle 2, I used 23 links in my chain and also needed two of the barclip.stl parts, and one each of extruder-chain-mount.stl, filament-cap.stl, and top-chain-mount.stl (as well as a spare 8mm rod to go in the barclip).

description.text:
This is a soroban abacus, a Japanese derivative of the Chinese suanpan.   
The parts print without support and are designed for simple assembly and a nice finish with no visible seams or fasteners.

Print 65 beads plus the inner and outer frame. I used bamboo skewers for the rods, but you can use 3mm filament instead if desired. In either case, the rods are 3mm, so make sure the holes in the beads and frame allow the rods to slide easily. A 1/8" drill works to clean these out. The rods should be trimmed flush to the outside of the inner frame. To assemble, insert the rods in the inner frame. For each rod place four beads in the large space, and one bead in the small space. Then slide the outer frame on with some glue. There are five small dots in the front used to mark every third row. The holes in the part can be filled with 1.75mm filament, wax, or paint, etc... Now that you have a nice looking and functional soroban, you can learn how to use it. Here are a few resources: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soroban
http://webhome.idirect.com/~totton/soroban/Manual.pdf
http://abacus.etherwork.net/soroban/
http://www.sorobanexam.org/

description.text: This is a dodecahedron created by friction welding 12 pentagons together. This is a minor remix to the truncated Icosahedron I previously published. The individual pentagons are printed separately. After printing the pentagons they are welded together using a Dremel rotary tool and a small section of printer filament. The friction welding process works for PLA, ABS, 1.75mm and 3mm filament. More information on the process used for friction welding this thing is available here: http://www.scorchworks.com/Blog/friction-welding-with-a-dremel-rotary-tool/ EDIT: I updated the SCAD file to make it more easily adjustable from a pentagon to other shapes and added comments.

description.text:
Some, (see comments at thing:30421), have asked for d10 dice. There are many d10 dice available on thingiverse, (see things 3018, 29055, 33392, 38156, and 58408). Several have the traditional form but other methods of construction are described. The earliest version, thing:3018 by TheRooster, is quite attractive. Here are four based on the standard pentagonal trapezohedron. OpenSCAD code is provided so that modifications can be made. All the dice have flat faces and should be easily printed. Provided are small and large dice, both plain and with flattened edges. Stl files are: d10_small.stl and d10_small_minkowski.stl
d10_large.stl and d10.large_minkowski.stl The pentagonal trapezohedron was constructed from a pentagonal antiprism by the method described in thing:30958. Numbers are taken from the font Architects Daughter by polymaker, thing:13677. The openSCAD program that created the dice is tp10_dice.scad and dxf images of the numbers are in numbers_dxf.zip. The flattened edge versions come from a minkowski sum of the pentagonal trapezohedron and its dual, the pentagonal antiprism. Examples of polyhedra produced by minkowski sums are included in the openSCAD program.
The dice can be printed directly on the build surface.  The small versions print in less than 30 minutes if a modest amount of infill is used.

title: Shopping trolley / Cart lock pick - with dummy Australian coins.

description.text:
UPDATE:
Printed coin pick and tested today - works like a charm and somewhat better that coat hangar version - printed in PLA.
Not tested yet - tab pick (the one to eject the coin)
*Dummy coins printed a touch under spec on my i2, my i3 is better calibrated but is waiting on new step sticks, and my self-designed machine is still in progress. I originally designed this tool from 2.5mm diameter coat hangar wire, when I was working as a trolley collector. The token system issued by the designers:
http://mrvsolutions.com/En/index.html
Just was too much of a pain to use when one has to collect over 1000 trolleys a day. If you understand the internal mechanism of the lock, you can use the second tool to eject a coin if it's still present in the trolley.
I'll get round to making a tutorial video on this at some stage. I have yet to print and test this design, but have included an image of an original prototype. Will post an update when I have - It's on the bed as we speak. I have also included coin dummies for Australian $1 and $2 coins.
Everything you need to get practiced with these tools on a budget. If you want to remix it - I'll gladly post the cad files. ------------------------------CAUTIONS!----------------------------------------
I don't want to hear what illegal things you get up to with these as I DO NOT condone breaking of the law.
Better yet - just don't do anything illegal with them.
FYI modern coin acceptors on nearly all vending machines know plastic from metal. Some even have cameras and GSM modems - you have been warned!

After having problems with jpearce's safety razor, I decided to try and fix it. After a few days of tinkering with it, I decided to address many of the design issues, practically reworking the entire thing from scratch. I give you my Koffin-Top safety razor. I liked the results so much, I use it every time I shave now. I hope you like it!
See it in action and learn more here: http://youtu.be/w4Xzr-y7T3w
Read the instructions for updates on this design!

Update: as of 8/14/2014:
Posted "perfect_handle_koffin_top.stl" scroll to the bottom for
details.
Update 7/17/2013:
I have added updated versions of the "Big-E-Koffin-Top.stl" file:
"Big-E-Koffin-Top_V2-Slim.stl" has a lower profile for a closer shave.
"Big-E-Koffin-Top_V2-Regular.stl" has a similar profile to the original top.
both these files are cleaned-up versions of the original, so you should use these new versions instead of the original "Big-E-Koffin-Top.stl" from now on. I am leaving up the original file, "Big-E-Koffin-Top.stl" for the sake of continuity, and for those who, for some strange reason, may prefer the original version.
Items needed:
an M3 nut and an M3 flat-top screw (M3x12 or M3x16 should do the job)
Some files and sandpaper a hobby knife will help with removing support from the handle portion.
Print the following files without support, at the highest resoulution you can, at 100% infill:
Big-E-Koffin-Top (V2_Regular or V2_Slim)
Big-E-Koffin-Top_Base
I printed at High resolution on my Replicator 2, this works best. the files have been correctly oriented to print properly.
Note as of 7/17/2013:
I've found Skeinforge is better for the top, Makerbot Slicer does an okay job, but, as of late (since Ver.2.2 of makerware) leaves some paper thin edges that expose less of the blade and may affect the quality of your shave. You can try MBSlicer; you may like the results better. I just prefer to use Skeinforge. I find that 100% infill and 2-3 shells works great.
Next, for the handle:
Big-E-Handle_needs_support
Print it as oriented, with raft and support turned on. Use the high-quality profile, as the supports will be removed more easily. this is the quickest way to print it. If possible, use ReplicatorG to print it instead for best results.
It should be printed with at least 3 shells and a good amount of infill (25-50%) 100% infill isn't required, but will make for a really solid handle. BTW, I borrowed elements from the 11th Doctor's sonic screwdriver by TheNewHobbyist ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:32065 ) when designing the handle; It makes for a comfortable and beefy grip, much like most old school safety razors.
Printing the "no-support" handle:
Download and print the file named "Big-E_Handle_flat_bottom.stl", You can print it without support on most printers. It will have a flat spot on the handle, and should already be oriented correctly for printing. To fill in the flat spot, and make a nice, round handle, download and print the file named "Big-E_Handle_flat_fill.stl" with tthe same settings as the flat bottom handle. use some super glue to attach the fill piece to the flat spot on the handle.
I still prefer printing the full handle with support, but I realise that some folks would rather print without it. You can always print the full "use support" handle upright, without support, but it will take longer to print, and may not be as strong as when printed on it's side. If you try this method, be sure to use as much infill as possible, and at the highest resolution you can. Now that I have cleaned up the model, it should be printable in this manner, without any random plastic strings or bits to clean up.
Either method you choose, those that may have had issues with the original version of the handle should be able to print it now.
If it's too much to print my handle, you can always use Jpearce's handle here, as it's compatible: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:43568
Lastly, you can print the cover I included, it's a version of Arkatipe's safety razor cover ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9686 ) scaled to fit the wider head of my razor design. I uploaded it here, already scaled for your convenience.
Thanks to Jpearce, TheNewHobbyist and Arkatipe for your originals, without which my version of a safety razor would not be possible!
Assemble like Jpearces razor. I like to add a drop or two of super glue to the nut once assembled, that way, the nut will stay put when disassembled later. I like to adjust the blade by it's sides before completely torquing down the screw. Once you get good at changing the blades, you will find you can do it without a screwdriver.
Note as of 7/17/2013:
I've just recently needed to print a new copy of the base and top. this is after 6 months of regular use. Over time, you may notice the blade's edge may pitch up in the middle, resulting in nicks. This is due to the plastic deforming and wearing over time. If you find you are nicking yourself more frequently, or the shave isn't as comfortable, despite changing the blade, it may be time for you to print a fresh base and top.
8/14/2014 my original handle broke, so it is time for a new one.
Due to changes in slicers, I have posted "perfect_handle_koffin_top.stl", which should be printable in the straight up position, without support using most slicers (I do use a raft, however, to ensure it stays on the plate) I suggest medium quality (.2mm layer height) with 3 shells and 15% infill. If previous versions of the handle give you grief, give it a shot.
If you make a derivative, please let me know prior to publishing it. Thanks!

title: Pentagonal Hook Piece
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This piece is designed to accept a chain or rope so that the polyhedra ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5961, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6178 ) can be hung from the ceiling. Specifically, I'm working on a soccer-ball shaped ( truncated icosahedral ) lamp using http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6055 as well as the pentagon from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5961. I need some way to hang the lamp. I believe p_hook_3 is the strongest design and least likely to fail by delamination. This piece also contains a slot for the lamp cord. This is compatible with other objects I've tagged with "Elements".

Print, trim the extra plastic from the hinges, combine at will with compatible parts. The scad script is a minor extension of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5961, so you could easily rework the design for other shapes. note on hinge clearance : The hinges can sometimes be a little tight. Make sure the first layer isn't pressed too far into the build platform. A compressed first layer will propagate up and make part of the hinge wider, decreasing the clearance. These parts are designed to fit tightly and may require pliers to assemble. If all else fails, removing some of the pins on the hinges can make assembly easier.

suggest printing this out of ABS plastic so that it holds up to higher temps. It will shrink though so you will need to print it at 101%
use a 1/8 inch drill bit to clean up the screw holes as well as for the rods. I had to chuck the drill bit only 1/8 inch in in order to clean thew the entire part but it works well. Also when this part is printing I looks very big compared to your current effector but the size is accurate.
Check swivel ends for fit and sand if necessary. I only had to sand a very small amount on it. Let me know what you guys think.

description.text:
A Hiragana chart, because there wasn't one on here already.  This chart is set up as an easy to reference object for helping to learn Japanese.  It does not include the "wi" or "we" Hiragana, as they are no longer in use.  It also does not include the modified (voiced) Hiragana for the p, b, d, z, and g sounds, which will have it's own model.  
If you want to learn how to pronounce Hiragana, youtube has several tutorials, I prefer the "Learn Japanese from Scratch" series by Tae Kim, and this chart is set up using the same layout he uses.

title: Winter landing gear for RCExplorer V3 (10mm booms)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Simple landing gear that zip ties to the 10mm booms of the RCExplorer. The added surface area prevents the tricopter from sinking into the snow. The added surface area also creates more drag when flying. It is a tradeoff. The landing gear gives the tricopter 72mm clearance between the ground and booms. Weighs about 11g depending on infill % Use the standalone leg (72mm) for summer use and add the standalone foot for winter use. Use a single 4mm zip tie to secure the leg to the 10mm boom. On hard impact the leg will rotate on the boom so be careful with placement of the ESCs on the boom (preferably place ESC on top or front of boom to prevent risk of damage on impact) Some tests: http://youtu.be/BwWds6JtMMY

comments.text: Hi cyclone, I fully agree if you put something on thingiverse it is to share with others, not to hide the files. I have a good mind to make this my first project but others may be quicker than me.
comments.author: cyclone

comments.text: I don't think it is necessary to alienate the designer but It should be understood that the reason you can't publish a thing without any files is because you are required to share the files if you post here. If you wish to keep the design to yourself and only sell physical prints of it then this isn't the place for your design. Shapeways, Pinshape and CGTrader allow designers to be much more restrictive in their business model.

comments.author: Michael__B

comments.text:
I wish I had that problem hah! I guess you just gotta wait for it to cool down and slowly prise it off with the plastic tool they provided. But making it stick firmly to the bed is very desirable as otherwise you could get corner warping or even the extruder getting stuck to the print and ruining the print (as well as potentially the nozzle cleaning device at the back - this almost happened to me when a huge sphere stuck to the head lol!)
gl

Nice work, from the photo that looks really crisp! As things go, probably the most important part of the print is the first layer so as soon as the bed is at the perfect height the prints start improving quickly ! enjoy the printer and let me know if u run into any other problems

comments.text: Thanks! Another thing that I changed is that I originally had the printer up on a metal and glass media table (originally made for a flat screen TV to sit on). The internal movement of the printer made the table shake. So I moved the printer to my basement with a concrete floor and put it up on rectangular stone slabs (to raise it up in case any water comes in) so it's got a really rigid platform and does not move at all.

remixed_from.author: dammitcoetzee
remixed_from.title: Filament Buddy. The helpful filament feed rate measuring tool.

description.text:
This tool helps you easily measure the amount of filament being extruded. Simply mark the top slot with a permenent marker, then extrude 50mm. Measure the difference between the two marks to get your e-step offset. Then get your new e-steps per mm with this equation
(Current E-Steps Per MM) * (50/(50-offset))
Make sure to get the sign of your offset right.

I recently got fed up with the loose spools of wiring material I have lying around, and designed this wire spool holder. I tried making it as universal as possible: -the triangles can stand on their own, or can be nounted to a board or onto the wall

title: Ruins of Machu Picchu - Temple of the Sun

description.text:
3D Printing for archaeology and architecture. VIDEO HERE:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9nOUBwsMy3Q Scientists have laser-scanned the ancient Incan ruins of Machu Picchu in Peru. You can work with the data to 3D print the ruins at home! +1000 Internet Points if you can design a roof for this temple. Source Data Credit (creative commons licensed):
http://gmv.cast.uark.edu/region-data/region/peru/machu-picchu-peru-temple-of-the-sun-2/ Credit: Instituto Nacional de Cultura, Center for Advanced Spatial Technologies, (University of Arkansas) andCotsen Institute for Archaeology (UCLA) Longer version: Data developed under the authority of the Instituto Nacional de Cultura, Vladimir DÃ¡vila â€“ Arquitecto del P.A.N Machu Picchu, Director del P.A.N Machu Picchu Direccion Regional de Cultura Cusco and Fernando Astete â€“ National Archaeological Park of Machu Picchu. Data acquired, processed and distributed by the Center for Advanced Spatial Technologies staff (Snow Winters, Malcolm Williamson and Katie Simon) and by students in the 2009 Cotsen Institute for Archaeology (UCLA) Cuzco/Machu Picchu Field School, Alexei Vranich Director.

I used Blender to import the raw point cloud surface mesh, cleaned it up, remeshed the file, removed doubles, recalculated normals outside, did a boolean union with a short cylinder as a platform. then we're done!
slice and print, and you're done.
makes a great gift!

title: Prusa i3 / P3Steel Improved Endstop Holders Collection

description.text:
This collection of parts includes what I consider to be the latest, best designs of X, Y and Z-axis endstop holders for any Prusa i3 variant, including the P3Steel and the Prusa i3 Twelvepro. Some of them I remixed, some are just as I found them here on Thingiverse or GitHub, and some I created in OpenSCAD. The Y-axis endstop holder parts set is my earlier thing #536752.
The Z-axis Makerbot-style endstop holder is my earlier thing #597093. It's a good match for the integrated fine-adjustment screw in my improved Prusa i3 / P3Steel X Motor End, found in my thing #607891.
The X-axis Makerbot-style endstop holder is an almost identical remix of thing #491859 by Abby Jones, very slightly stronger than the original. There are two versions of the endstop holders for each axis: one holds a small limit switch (standard size), and the other (which I recommend) holds a Makerbot-style mechanical endstop. All these designs include the OpenSCAD source and are released under the GPLV3 with proper attribution.
Printed in PLA with 35% infill and 0.6mm walls and top/bottom layers.

comments.text: Well... In my 2 year reprapping time, I have never had need to adjust my X endstop. I might be missing something tho...
comments.author: AndrewBCN

comments.text:
The X and Y-axis endstops are typically adjusted when the printer is built, once all the parts are in place (including the extruder), so that the maximum printable heatbed area is available. These endstops rarely need to be adjusted later, unless some printer part is changed.
The Z-axis endstop is a slightly different case, because (at least in my experience) sometimes one needs to adjust it slightly up or down (that's why I use a screw on the X-Motor End to adjust it).

description.text:
The only reason i had to connect my computer to my printer was to change the filament.
With these g-codes it belongs to the past.
Put the files standard on the printer sd-cards for a careless, quick and easy, stand alone PLA (210°C) filament change.
Select to remove the old filament the "retract-file" and select the "extrude-file" to feed the new one.
If you want to clean the nozzle from the old filament run the "exrude-file" at least twice to get rid of the previous color or wood fibres.
Tested and proven on a Felix 3.0
